SIX NEW MEMBERS

BANQUET THURSDAY NIGHT
John Sherwood Outlines Aims
at Assembly Initiation

Left to right; Gwinn, Abraham, McNeal, Rodgers, Passano,
and Stone

SCHEIBEL TO HEAD
1927 BARRIERS
Herman Scheibel was elected captain of the 1927 cross
country team at a meeting
held last Saturday. Scheibel
will be a Junior next year and
should be the mainstay of the
team.
Six men will be back from
this year's team: Scheibel,
Scheidt, Kelly, Waters, Kirkpatrick, and Wheeler. Past
performances of the team indicate that next year's team will
be a well-balanced one. ActivitieS of the harriers will
wind up tomorrow with the
running of the South Atlantic
Cross Country Run.

INQUIRIES COME IN FOR
JOBS NEXT YEAR
Dr. French

Five seniors and one junior were
publicly initiated into the Omicron
Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity
before the Assembly yesterday.
The recipients of the laurel leaf, insignia of the organization, were formally initiated at a banquet at the
Southern Hotel last night. The
men who received the honor are J.
Albert Abraham, G. Richards
Gwinn, Thomas F. McNeal, Edward M. Passano, Brinton H.
Stone, seniors, and I. Evans Rodgers, a junior.
John Sherwood, '23, made the
initial address, outlining the purposes and aims of Omicron Delta
Kappa. Following his talk, Secretary Maxwell Cone read out the
names of the initiates, who stepped
forward and received their laurel
leaves, and were congratulated by
the members of the fraternity. Cone
then read out the list of the initiates'
activities on the campus.

MRS. B. P. WARREN

In the life of nearly every man there are moments which
are worth months or even years of the humdrum routine of existence. Usually preceded by long periods of hard work and solid
achievement, and remembered after the long intervening gaps are
forgotten, they are the moments which make life really worth
living. Supreme among undergraduate triumphs at Hopkins, and
perhaps unsurpassed by any in later life, are the emotions which
crowd upon each man who is called to walk up the aisle of the
Assembly Hall to receive the laurel leaf of Omicron Delta Kappa.
For 0. D. K. represents the best in undergraduate life,
whether it be in scholarships, athletics, or non-athletic activities,
or, above all, in one's relations with his fellow man. The man
who is admitted to membership has succeeded; he has received
the most sought after college honor, and has gained an opportunity for still broader service to the University. The NEWSLETTER wishes to congratulate the six men who were chosen yesterday. They were wisely selected. Each in his own way has
given his best to Hopkins. Each one by his achievements and by
the spirit in which he has carried on his work has proved himself worthy of that old Greek symbol of victory—the laurel leaf.

THE SWIMMING TEAM
From a front page article in the last issue of the NEWSLETTER, together with a wretched picture which looked more like
a Bhudda of some third-rate Oriental artist than the stalwart
captain of the swimming team whose name was beneath it, we
learn that the swimming team is, still very much in existence, and
is planning an ambitious schedule.
The swimming team deserves support because swimming is
the one winter sport of Hopkins, if for no other reason. There
are, however, a great many other reasons. Teams in the past
have been successful, even though they have usually picked strong
opponents. Prospects for this year look exceptionally bright.
Aside from the question of winning or losing meets, swimming
is interesting to the spectator, or at least we have found it so.
We always have enjoyed watching the mermen splashing up and
down the pool, even though we have been considerably drenched
by the spray on several occasions. To round off the evening, the
dances which follow the meets have in the past proved enjoyable.
The team does not receive a very large sum from the Athletic
Association; it depends to a large extent to the attendance at
home meets. If the students want swimming, and we feel that
they do, the only way to show this interest is to support the home
meets.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1926
POET CONTRIBUTES TO THE
NEWS-LETTER MAILBAG
Continued from Page 4, Col. 1
To places unknown, on seas unknown—
But never a care had we.
There were days when we sat
astern at the wheel
And sailed on a pleasing course
As a west'ly breeze did fill our
sails
And the sun beat warmly down.
Along the shoals a-beam of us
Some rock broke near a net,
So we wished for time to cast our
line
And cook some fish at noon.
When the sun grew hot we'd
swab the deck
To cool its heated planks;
We'd fetch the jug from down below
And drink of its cool contents.
Then we'd light a pipe, and sit
again
And sail away in peace.
But then there were days when
we stood a-stern,
Clad in our old oil skins,
And watched the skies as the rain
beat down
Drenching us to the skin.
The wind had shifted toward the
East
And a storm lay in the West
So, soon it came with wind and
rain
And the sea rose up and tossed.
And bound across our deck and
rail;
But never a care had we
With jib furled tight, and the
main-sheet down,
And the hatches down so tight,
The anchor cast, with its cable
fast
About the nigger-head.
But all in all let the weather be
For storms must come and go:
So we sail on our forward course,
Where ever we are bound, •
As the foam springs up on the leeward rail
Then washes across the hatch,—
But we hold our places a'stern at
the wheel
And sail a pleasant course
To places unknown, on seas unknown
But never a care have we.
S. V. C.

He had always wanted
a business

of his own

HowARD D. EGE

“What's thefuture with a
large organization?" That
college men want to know;
what
is
first of all. The question is best
answered by the accomplishments
'If others With similar training
and like opportunities. This is
one of a series of advertisements
portraying the progress at Westinghouse of typical college graduat4s, off the campus some five
—eight—ten years.

4:1C

—and now, while lie docsn't own
the business, he's got what he
had hoped for in a business of
his own. He's gained the opportunity to bring out the best there
is in human effort—to handle
men rather than materials.
That's what Howard D. Ege
had in mind during the time of
his early schooling at Grand
Island College. It was actively
developed during 1919-21 when
he worked nights in a Lawrence
power plant while completing the
work for his B. S. in Engineering at Kansas University.
Ege doesn't scorn the wellknown dictum of Socrates—
"Know thyself" But he gets
more of a kick out of the practical application of"Know others."

for coordinating the efforts of
soo employees—half of them
men and half of them women—
on the production floor.
Ege is Production Supervisor
in the Coils and Insulation Department at the East Pittsburgh
Works. He is the link between
the entire Westinghouse organization and thirteen foremen who
directly supervise the work of
hundreds of employees. He is
engaged in a production job
which turns out finished parts
with a shop value of more than
$1,000,000 a y ear.

Today—five years after en rolling in the Westinghouse
Graduate Students' Course—he
directly controls a staff of fifty
persons. And he's responsible

How Westinghouse offers
opportunity to engineers differing widely in outlook is demonstrated again in Ege's case:
From the time he conceived his

ambition to work with men his
path has followed a straight line.
His training course at East Pittsburgh was in Works Management. This lasted about a year.
Then he became Chief Clerk in
the Coils and Insulation Department. Only one year later he
became Supervisor, reporting
directly to the Works Superintendent of Production.
To the man who wants to
work with men rather than with
materials, Westinghouse offers
promising opportunities.

Westinghouse

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1926

4

A. H. FETTING
ENTIRE FOURTH FLOOR TO
MANUFACTURING JEWELRY
BE UTILIZED
CO.
Study Room and R. 0. T. C. to
Occupy Old Psychology Quarters

Mr. Otho Ryan, Superintendent
of Buildings, has just moved his
office to the fourth floor of Gilman
Hall, taking over one of the rooms
formerly occupied by the psychology department.
The rooms that the military and
physical training departments are
to occupy have been remodeled and
are ready for occupancy. Major
Hoisington stated that he would
move as soon as the. new telephones,
which have been ordered, arrive.
' The remodeling of the other
rooms has not been completed. The
workingmen expect to finish by
TuesdaS, or Wednesday, and then
begin repairing the present military
office for the political economy department.
All the rooms on the fourth floor
will be occupied, it was decided. A
section of the south loft being used
as a study room.

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
The sophomores won the football
game and tied the rush. Consequently, if I am not mistaken, the
freshman must continue to wear
regulations. And the Pep Committee is to enforce frosh rules.
But why is it that every day I
see freshmen with vivid-hued hose,
gaudy ties, no freshman or activities
buttons? Where is the Pep Com-

To beat upon your face,
To wet your hair, your arms, and
breast
And dry in a Nor'west breeze.

past,

SCHEIBEL TO HEAD
1927 BARRIERS
Herman Scheibel was elected captain of the 1927 cross
country team at a meeting
held last Saturday. Scheibel
will be a Junior next year and
should be the mainstay of the
team.
Six men will be back from
this year's team: Scheibel,
Scheidt, Kelly, Waters, Kirkpatrick, and Wheeler. Past
performances of the team indicate that next year's team will
be a well-balanced one. ActivitieS of the harriers will
wind up tomorrow with the
running of the South Atlantic
Cross Country Run.

INQUIRIES COME IN FOR
JOBS NEXT YEAR
Dr. French

Five seniors and one junior were
publicly initiated into the Omicron
Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity
before the Assembly yesterday.
The recipients of the laurel leaf, insignia of the organization, were formally initiated at a banquet at the
Southern Hotel last night. The
men who received the honor are J.
Albert Abraham, G. Richards
Gwinn, Thomas F. McNeal, Edward M. Passano, Brinton H.
Stone, seniors, and I. Evans Rodgers, a junior.
John Sherwood, '23, made the
initial address, outlining the purposes and aims of Omicron Delta
Kappa. Following his talk, Secretary Maxwell Cone read out the
names of the initiates, who stepped
forward and received their laurel
leaves, and were congratulated by
the members of the fraternity. Cone
then read out the list of the initiates'
activities on the campus.

MRS. B. P. WARREN

In the life of nearly every man there are moments which
are worth months or even years of the humdrum routine of existence. Usually preceded by long periods of hard work and solid
achievement, and remembered after the long intervening gaps are
forgotten, they are the moments which make life really worth
living. Supreme among undergraduate triumphs at Hopkins, and
perhaps unsurpassed by any in later life, are the emotions which
crowd upon each man who is called to walk up the aisle of the
Assembly Hall to receive the laurel leaf of Omicron Delta Kappa.
For 0. D. K. represents the best in undergraduate life,
whether it be in scholarships, athletics, or non-athletic activities,
or, above all, in one's relations with his fellow man. The man
who is admitted to membership has succeeded; he has received
the most sought after college honor, and has gained an opportunity for still broader service to the University. The NEWSLETTER wishes to congratulate the six men who were chosen yesterday. They were wisely selected. Each in his own way has
given his best to Hopkins. Each one by his achievements and by
the spirit in which he has carried on his work has proved himself worthy of that old Greek symbol of victory—the laurel leaf.

THE SWIMMING TEAM
From a front page article in the last issue of the NEWSLETTER, together with a wretched picture which looked more like
a Bhudda of some third-rate Oriental artist than the stalwart
captain of the swimming team whose name was beneath it, we
learn that the swimming team is, still very much in existence, and
is planning an ambitious schedule.
The swimming team deserves support because swimming is
the one winter sport of Hopkins, if for no other reason. There
are, however, a great many other reasons. Teams in the past
have been successful, even though they have usually picked strong
opponents. Prospects for this year look exceptionally bright.
Aside from the question of winning or losing meets, swimming
is interesting to the spectator, or at least we have found it so.
We always have enjoyed watching the mermen splashing up and
down the pool, even though we have been considerably drenched
by the spray on several occasions. To round off the evening, the
dances which follow the meets have in the past proved enjoyable.
The team does not receive a very large sum from the Athletic
Association; it depends to a large extent to the attendance at
home meets. If the students want swimming, and we feel that
they do, the only way to show this interest is to support the home
meets.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1926
POET CONTRIBUTES TO THE
NEWS-LETTER MAILBAG
Continued from Page 4, Col. 1
To places unknown, on seas unknown—
But never a care had we.
There were days when we sat
astern at the wheel
And sailed on a pleasing course
As a west'ly breeze did fill our
sails
And the sun beat warmly down.
Along the shoals a-beam of us
Some rock broke near a net,
So we wished for time to cast our
line
And cook some fish at noon.
When the sun grew hot we'd
swab the deck
To cool its heated planks;
We'd fetch the jug from down below
And drink of its cool contents.
Then we'd light a pipe, and sit
again
And sail away in peace.
But then there were days when
we stood a-stern,
Clad in our old oil skins,
And watched the skies as the rain
beat down
Drenching us to the skin.
The wind had shifted toward the
East
And a storm lay in the West
So, soon it came with wind and
rain
And the sea rose up and tossed.
And bound across our deck and
rail;
But never a care had we
With jib furled tight, and the
main-sheet down,
And the hatches down so tight,
The anchor cast, with its cable
fast
About the nigger-head.
But all in all let the weather be
For storms must come and go:
So we sail on our forward course,
Where ever we are bound, •
As the foam springs up on the leeward rail
Then washes across the hatch,—
But we hold our places a'stern at
the wheel
And sail a pleasant course
To places unknown, on seas unknown
But never a care have we.
S. V. C.

Ege is Production Supervisor
in the Coils and Insulation Department at the East Pittsburgh
Works. He is the link between
the entire Westinghouse organization and thirteen foremen who

How Westinghouse offers
opportunity to engineers differing widely in outlook is demonstrated again in Ege's case:
From the time he conceived his

ambition to work with men his
path has followed a straight line.
His training course at East Pittsburgh was in Works Management. This lasted about a year.
Then he became Chief Clerk in
the Coils and Insulation Department. Only one year later he
became Supervisor, reporting
directly to the Works Superintendent of Production.
To the man who wants to
work with men rather than with
materials, Westinghouse offers
promising opportunities.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 17, 1926

4

A. H. FETTING
ENTIRE FOURTH FLOOR TO
MANUFACTURING JEWELRY
BE UTILIZED
CO.
Study Room and R. 0. T. C. to
Occupy Old Psychology Quarters

Mr. Otho Ryan, Superintendent
of Buildings, has just moved his
office to the fourth floor of Gilman
Hall, taking over one of the rooms
formerly occupied by the psychology department.
The rooms that the military and
physical training departments are
to occupy have been remodeled and
are ready for occupancy. Major
Hoisington stated that he would
move as soon as the. new telephones,
which have been ordered, arrive.
' The remodeling of the other
rooms has not been completed. The
workingmen expect to finish by
TuesdaS, or Wednesday, and then
begin repairing the present military
office for the political economy department.
All the rooms on the fourth floor
will be occupied, it was decided. A
section of the south loft being used
as a study room.

PEP UP-PEP COMITTEE!
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
The sophomores won the football
game and tied the rush. Consequently, if I am not mistaken, the
freshman must continue to wear
regulations. And the Pep Committee is to enforce frosh rules.
But why is it that every day I
see freshmen with vivid-hued hose,
gaudy ties, no freshman or activities
buttons? Where is the Pep Com-

A POET'S CONTRIBUTION
It makes you blue, when von start
to think
Of those summer days just past,
When the sun danced jigs upon
the waves
And the lee-rail stayed just und2r ;
As the water swished, and the
foam sprang up
To beat upon your face,
To wet your hair, your arms, and
breast
And dry in a Nor'west breeze.
Those were the days of a summer
past,
When the mind and heart were
gay,
And the days were long, and the
moon was bright,
As we sailed on our careless way

mittee?
Ever since that estimable group
of youths got oVer the excitement
of being elected to the Pep Committee and since rushing season is over,
they have left their paddles at home.
Freshmen walk brazenly on the
campus without regulations, and the
men on the committee look the other way. Only on Thursday at Assembly an occasional paddle Vill appear.
If freshman rules are to be enforced, let tilt men charged with
enforcing them get to work. Otherwise abolish the rules. At least don't
make a joke of the whole thing—
and that is what it is at present.
